items.title: Retrieve error details when deployment fails
items.body:
The error typically looks like the following:

```
WARNING: Attempt 1 failed: Exception calling "Invoke" with "0" argument(s): "The running command stopped because the preference variable "ErrorActionPreference" or common parameter is set to Stop: 5:56:26 PM - Error: Code=InvalidTemplateDeployment; Message=The template deployment 't82fbaa9f596c4475' is not valid according to the validation procedure. The tracking id is 'be8b2db7-c0c7-4904-a27a-a9c9c6e4a1ab'. See inner errors for details.
". Trying again in 10 seconds...
WARNING: Attempt 2 failed: Exception calling "Invoke" with "0" argument(s): "The running command stopped because the preference variable "ErrorActionPreference" or common parameter is set to Stop: 5:56:38 PM - Error: Code=InvalidTemplateDeployment; Message=The template deployment 't82fbaa9f596c4475' is not valid according to the validation procedure. The tracking id is 'a600ec4e-5010-40b2-8e00-ea26ab7397ae'. See inner errors for details.
". Trying again in 20 seconds...
WARNING: Attempt 3 failed: Exception calling "Invoke" with "0" argument(s): "The running command stopped because the preference variable "ErrorActionPreference" or common parameter is set to Stop: 5:56:59 PM - Error: Code=InvalidTemplateDeployment; Message=The template deployment 't82fbaa9f596c4475' is not valid according to the validation procedure. The tracking id is 'b82ea305-9db8-4950-a762-61a97027e459'. See inner errors for details.
". Trying again in 40 seconds...
WARNING: Attempt 4 failed: Exception calling "Invoke" with "0" argument(s): "The running command stopped because the preference variable "ErrorActionPreference" or common parameter is set to Stop: 5:57:41 PM - Error: Code=InvalidTemplateDeployment; Message=The template deployment 't82fbaa9f596c4475' is not valid according to the validation procedure. The tracking id is '3249a7b0-c97e-4766-9de6-9a7e3dc82d76'. See inner errors for details.
". Trying again in 80 seconds...
```

We should be calling `Get-AzureRMLog -CorrelationId xxxxx` to get more information and make it easier to debug failures.

items.title: testit
testit
ShipReady report showing incorrect areas
items.body: The ShipReady report is showing some JS pipelines in their own area due to the way that JS live test pipelines are configured. This just needs to be cleaned up in the report to accommodate that data shape (will be a whack-a-mole exercise).

items.title: Classifier for PowerShell failures
items.body:
We are seeing periodic failures for PowerShell module installation:
https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build/results?buildId=474805&view=results

We should write a classifier to make sure we can quantify these issues.

items.title: APIStubGen is failing for azure.ai.textanalytics due to meta folder
items.body: APIStubGen finds a module "azure.ai" in Azure.ai.textanalytics package due to _init.py in that folder but this is not a module. API stub generator should be modified to look for modules that starts with root name space only.

items.title: Add query to the emails that get sent out regarding customer reported issues in invalid state
items.body:
We now have a system where we get sent an email every week for customer reported issues in an invalid state.
It would be great if the email had a link to the GitHub query for such issues so that as and when we work on fixing the state, we get an updated view

cc @AlexGhiondea

items.title: API View: Add the ability to label revisions
items.body:
We need the ability to label revisions to indicate which ones are GA revisions (and which versions), and give names corresponding to features/changes to other revisions. For example,

Revision 0: Prototype
Revision 1: Preview 1
Revision 2: Feature A
Revision 3: Feature B
Revision 4: Preview 2
Revision 5: GA V1
....

items.title: Unmute your microphone Scott.
Unify approach to cosmos emulator download and install steps
items.body:
We have 3 separate approaches to downloading and installing cosmos db: 

* Java: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/blob/master/eng/pipelines/templates/stages/cosmos-sdk-client.yml#L116
* JS: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-js/blob/master/eng/pipelines/templates/steps/cosmos-integration-public.yml 
* Python: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/master/eng/pipelines/templates/stages/cosmos-sdk-client.yml#L44

These should be unified into one process (note Java has extra steps around the certificate) and placed in our `eng/common` area so all languages can use the same set of pipelines. 

Also, https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/issues/12970 can be solved this way by not using `Invoke-WebRequest` when downloading the emulator for Java.

items.title: VerifyChangeLogEntry step fails for private repo.
items.body:
See example https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build/results?buildId=451689&view=logs&j=b70e5e73-bbb6-5567-0939-8415943fadb9&t=72c41882-9d21-5580-4869-7f3ea1bd9c0a

Logic at https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/blob/master/eng/common/scripts/Verify-ChangeLog.ps1#L27 
```
 $Language = $RepoName.Substring($RepoName.LastIndexOf('-') + 1)
```
fails for our private repos that are named like `azure-sdk-for-js-pr`

We probably should start explicitly passing in the language or importing a common variable file for each repo that has common properties like language.

items.title: Pipeline Witness classifier for Maven artifact downloads
items.body:
We see transient build failures due to downloads of Maven artifacts. The most recent example was in the Spotbugs step where it was hitting Maven Central directly instead of using our proxy. That has been addressed, however even with using the proxy we can still see periodic issues.

We need a classifier which can detect these issues regardless of where they occur (could occur in any step that triggers a Maven goal) and look through the logs for the errors that indicate artifact download problems. It is possible that mucking with the Maven Wagon settings could help this but I want to first get a sense of magnitude of the problem and establish a baseline.

items.title: [apiview] Incorrect generated type annotation for python api view
items.body:
I have a type annotation that is `Union[List[str], List[DetectLanguageInput], List[Dict[str, str]]]` (link to code [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/master/sdk/textanalytics/azure-ai-textanalytics/azure/ai/textanalytics/_text_analytics_client.py#L93)) and it's being displayed incorrectly in the apiview

[apiview link](https://apiview.dev/Assemblies/Review/f74ef8c4777b408f85dab76b8034cb41?diffRevisionId=86e49dc083f14c55a13f47bb8e769937) and picture
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43154838/86822474-ad47af00-c059-11ea-9f3e-67b5ca85f6ca.png)

items.title: Change python API view process to upload whl instead of json
items.body:
Currently python team generates json token file using apistubgen and uploads json to apiview tool. Problem with this approach is that api view tool wont be able to regenerate the listing when api view  itself is changed. If whl is uploaded, then tool will make changes to api listing when api listing format is changed.

Change required is to get script based execution ready for python and get python team on board this new approach.

items.title: Verify Changelog script output is messed up when an error occurs
items.body:
See example at https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build/results?buildId=448786&view=logs&j=149e1b6d-5e4a-5703-203b-da6e3c2198c0&t=7716d7a8-7bbc-5ac3-84b9-3642e484df5b&s=271b10a9-e6f6-5448-24f0-408485e4df2e

```

Starting: Verify ChangeLog / Release Notes
==============================================================================
Task         : PowerShell
Description  : Run a PowerShell script on Linux, macOS, or Windows
Version      : 2.170.1
Author       : Microsoft Corporation
Help         : https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/utility/powershell
==============================================================================
Generating script.
Formatted command: . '/home/vsts/work/1/s/eng/common/scripts/Verify-ChangeLog.ps1' -PackageName azure-identity -ServiceName identity -RepoRoot /home/vsts/work/1/s -RepoName Azure/azure-sdk-for-java -ForRelease $True
========================== Starting Command Output ===========================
/usr/bin/pwsh -NoLogo -NoProfile -NonInteractive -Command . '/home/vsts/work/_temp/e9452b62-c7c6-4621-9d68-5ed307bc161d.ps1'
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Installing package 'powershell-yaml'                                               Downloaded 0.00 MB out of 0.29 MB.                                              [                                                                    ]                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      ##[warning]Incorrect Date: Please use the current date in the Changelog '/home/vsts/work/1/s/sdk/identity/azure-identity/CHANGELOG.md' before releasing the package

##[error]PowerShell exited with code '1'.
Finishing: Verify ChangeLog / Release Notes
```
The error shows way off the screen and it is because of the Show-Progress dialog for the import-module.

To fix this I think we should disable the progress preference in the script before we call Import-Module the first time.

See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_preference_variables?view=powershell-7#progresspreference

FYI @JimSuplizio

items.title: apistubgen error message for "failed to import" does not provide enough detail about specific exception
items.body:
I manually added methods signatures/properties/classes in to azure-eventgrid for APIView, but I did not implement all methods. When I ran `apistubgen --pkg-path ..\..\..\..\..\azure-sdk-for-python\sdk\eventgrid\azure-eventgrid\ --out-path <output-path>`, it threw the following exception:
```ERROR:root:Failed to import azure.eventgrid
ERROR:root:Failed to import azure.eventgrid.version
ERROR:root:Failed to import azure.eventgrid.aio
ERROR:root:Failed to import azure.eventgrid.aio.operations_async
ERROR:root:Failed to import azure.eventgrid.models
ERROR:root:Failed to import azure.eventgrid.operations
```

After I modified the _stub_generator.py file to log the specific exception, I saw that the error was because I called a method that I had not defined: 
`ERROR:root:Excepted with:  name '_initialize_mapping' is not defined`.

The error was on my end, but more specific error messages would have been useful. The fix I made was the following, in line 182, `azure-sdk-tools\packages\python-packages\api-stub-generator\apistub\_stub_generator.py`:
```
except Exception as e:
    logging.error("Excepted with:  {}".format(e))
```

items.title: Automatically apply PR labels based on changes in PR
items.body: Based on a request from @ramya-rao-a we want to have a mechanism that knows how to apply a label based on the changes in a pull request. This would use the existing ```CODEOWNERS``` file if possible. At the moment the ```@``` symbol is used on each line of the ```CODEOWNERS``` file to designate a user who is responsible for files that match that pattern. My proposal is that we make use of another symbol (for example ```%``` to designate a label). Hopefully the ```%``` symbol would be gracefully ignored by GitHub itself.

items.title: ApiView: Show a list of all unresolved comments and a link to the revision they were added

It's hard to track unresolved comments across API changes when the feature team updates ApiView frequently.  I would love an optional tab next to "Revisions" called "Unresolved" that lists every unresolved comment, links to the ApiView revision where the comment was added, and optionally includes which revision made it hidden.

https://apiview.dev/Assemblies/Review/cf2c57b3d4c44ef08c2e8284f7441a2d is a good example of how this feature would be really useful.

items.title: Fix Pipeline Witness client-reuse
items.body:
Pipeline Witness is not reusing (indirectly) HTTP client instances. As a result the function instances are building up their collection count (particularly if a lot of events arrive at once). This causes the Azure Functions health check to kick in and stop the function executing.

We aren't losing any messages as a result, but our exception logs get poluted with ```InvalidOperationExceptions``` as a result of the health check failing. In previous function implementations I've seen client reuse help mitigate this issue.

items.title: Remove-TestResources.ps1 should clean up env file if exists
items.body: If `-OutFile` was passed to *New-TestResources.ps1*, a file is created. We should test for this file unconditionally and delete it if deleting the resource group is successful so we don't leave secrets lying around, which 1) could expose information (some of it, like for SPs, might still be relevant), and 2) would cause downstream test errors instead of easier errors like `SEARCH_API_KEY not found` (or similar).

items.title: Decide naming convention for package id in the case of monolithic releases
items.body:
Most releases today are at the level of a package, for example `Azure.Storage.Files.Shares` ... The release tags take the form of `<package_id>_<version>` example: `Azure.Storage.Files.Shares_12.2.1` 

In the case of releasing a monolithic entity like the entire C SDK the package identity may not be as straightforward. What should the `<package_id>` portion (if any) of the release name be? 

In the case of the C SDK today we assume there is no package identity and the release tag takes the form of `<version>` (e.g. `1.0.0-preview.1`). Should this include a package identity?

items.title: Add analyzer for JSON types in public API surface
Test resource removal should always run
items.body:
`remove-test-resources.yml` used to have conditions that implicitly included success or failure from previous steps as criteria for executing: 

https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/commit/6c10784d9d247e4aeb698719960a5ee8d4eafa30#diff-321c59d996cb4fd201d93ed3fbd93309L22

```yaml
    condition: and(ne(variables['AZURE_RESOURCEGROUP_NAME'], ''), eq(variables['CloudType'], 'AzureCloud'))
```

This now should be: 

```yaml
condition: and(ne(variables['AZURE_RESOURCEGROUP_NAME'], ''), always())
```

or

```yaml
condition: and(ne(variables['AZURE_RESOURCEGROUP_NAME'], ''), succeededOrFailed())
```

Whilst its simple enough that exceptions are generally a pretty good way to diagnose what is going on, we ran into an instance in one of the functions overnight where it failed to route messages because it appeared the an environment variable was not set on that particular instance (how is that even possible?).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/513398/81888765-6606ea00-95e5-11ea-9d51-256dbfc34184.png)

We need to keep an eye on this particular variable, but to do that we would need to plumb through the logger interface to the router and start using it more extensively than we are today.

items.title: Pipeline Witness service
items.body:
As part of the pipeline health metrics work we need to collect pipeline run details so that we can easily query it for reporting purposes. The way we are going to approach his is that we are going to have a service that listens to the notifications from Azure Pipelines as pipelines are completed (pass or fail).

We'll then download the full pipeline run JSON payload as well as associated meta data such as timeline records. We'll store the raw JSON in blob storage so that if the run is deleted for whatever reason that we can still get the data for analysis purposes.

The Pipeline Witness will then process these files into a more queryable format that can be used by Power BI and mashed up with other data.

items.title: [Apiview] Exclude inherited documented methods from lint check
items.body: Method like close, get, has_key, items, keys, update, values should be excluded from lint check for Python packages.

items.title: Add analyzer for client method return types
items.body: Should allow `Response<T>/[Async]Pageable<T>/ClientClasses` and derived types

items.title: Disable CI triggers for our generated pipelines
items.body: Based on some recent analysis our CI builds account for about 20-25% of all our agent usage in our internal team project and they can cause interruptions for our manual releases and PR validation if a number of them kick off at the same time. Given that we have a scheduled build for each pipeline daily and that we can still trigger them manually or via a PR comment I think we should disable our CI triggers because they don't seem to add enough value for their cost.

items.title: Reliability pass on Check Enforcer
items.body:
We need to do a reliability pass on Check Enforcer. There are three categories of issue which are currently impacting the user experience:

1. Rate limiting from GitHub
2. Race conditions resulting in errors marking checks as successful.
3. Lost Check Run webhooks

In terms of overall request count these issues don't impact the service too much but it is annoying if you happen to be sitting on a PR that is impacted by any of them. Here are some suggested fixes:

1. GitHub rate limiting; switch over from direct HTTP trigger processing to using Event Hubs via the Webhook Router. This would allow us to process the web hooks asynchronously and when rate limiting occurs simply back off and retry.

2. Race conditions; I haven't been able to pin this down, but I believe that the creation of check-runs on the GitHub side is not atomic meaning that we could get into a situation where we create two Check Runs. Unfortunately there is a bug in our code where we filter the _check-enforcer_ check-runs via ```SingleOrDefault()```. This results in an exception and notifications that could potentially result in Check Enforcer passing never get processed completely. We need to adapt to a model where we check for one or more check-runs and if more than one exists simply update both Check Runs.

3. Lost check-run webhooks; GitHub does not retry sending webhooks. Transient network issues, delays spinning up function apps (redeployments for example) can result in webhooks getting lost. To mitigate this we should consider having a timer based trigger which goes to the GitHub app API and retries messages that failed (up to a certain sunset period). Some thought would be need to be put into whether we want this to be a generic facility that we put into the webhook router to help make everything that runs through it more resilient or just have it as something specific to Check Enforcer.

items.title: deploy-test-resources.yml needs -SubscriptionId parameter
items.body:
In the interest of avoiding having to repeat secret names we've hard-coded secret names into deploy-test-resources.yml. To enable testing in our Test Resources and Test Resources - Preview subscriptions we need to be able to supply different values to `-SubscriptionId` 

https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/blob/master/eng/common/TestResources/deploy-test-resources.yml#L23

items.title: Handling no-pipeline scenarios in Check Enforcer
items.body:
Over the last couple of days there have been quite a few instances of PRs making changes where no Azure Pipeline was run. it might have been a README.md change that isn't covered by a pipeline, or some other configuration change. I'm starting this discussion to try and figure out what we want out stance to be on this.

Just a refresher on how Check Enforcer works. Check Enforcer has a setting called ```minimumCheckRuns```stored in its configuration file located at ```eng/CHECKENFORCER``` in each repository. The way Check Enforcer interprets this setting is that when it gets a check-run completed event it evaluates first whether all outstanding check runs have passed (excluding itself) and that the total number of check runs (excluding itself) meets or exceeds the minimumCheckRuns threshold.

In the case of no-pipeline PRs this threshold is not met, and so Check Enforcer remains in-progress and what change to its successful state.

> **Argument for leaving as is:**
> One of the arguments for leaving the status quo is that no-pipeline runs are a bit of a EngSys "smell" in that there might be some classes of changes where automated validation doesn't occur and additional manual verification, and administrative merge rights are required.

> **Argument for changing behavior:**
> On the flip side, there are plenty of changes which are innocuous and we shouldn't be blocking teams from getting things done whilst they hunt for an administrator to merge their change.

We first need to determine where we land on the above arguments and then, if we decide that a behavior change is required determine the best approach.

There are a few possibilities that would need exploration. One option would be to add an ignore glob patterns to the ```eng/CHECKENFORCER``` such that if a PR in its entirety is covered by the ignore pattern that Check Enforcer would turn green. There might be some other options although this one could be done in a stateless way without too much overhead.

items.title: [api-stub-generator] Python api stub generator display problems
items.body:
- **Package Name**: api-stub-generator
- **Package Version**: master
- **Operating System**: Windows
- **Python Version**: 3.7

**Describe the bug**
Using azure-eventhub `EventHubProducerClient.send_batch` display in the apiview tool as an example.
1. The "*" of the method signature is omitted.
2. Two false alarm. This async method doesn't have **kwargs. And it had type hints for every param. But the type hint is different from the python2 style.
   - "Keyword arg (**kwargs) is missing in API send_batch Details", 
   - "Typehint is missing for API send_batch Details".
3. Data type is updated in a new revision. But the data type is still from an old revision. 
For instance, "event_data_batch: EventDataBatch" is in revision0. It's been updated to "event_data_batch: Union[EventDataBatch, List[EventData]]" in revision1. The old data type is shown in revision 1.
4. In some methods, "Dict[str, Any]" is shown as "DictnDict[str, Any]". "List[str]" is shown as "ListnList[str]"

items.title: Make common test resource variables always available
Nightly run scheduler for Azure Pipelines
items.body:
As the number of services, language repositories and resulting pipelines expands we are starting to see periods during the day where scheduled pipeline runs are causing backlogs in our build pools. We've been looking at mechanisms to analyze all our scheduled jobs and bucket their start times but this doesn't really stop the potential for some combination of jobs to chew up all the capacity and block PR/CI runs.

Rather than use Azure Pipelines scheduling which is fairly static, I am proposing a more dynamic system where we have a function that runs, analyzes the current state of the agent pool and then based on that signal selects from the set of test runs it knows it needs to schedule and queues them.

The system would not schedule jobs if the pool was running above a certain threshold to ensure that test runs never block PRs. The logic would roughly be as follows:

1. Check agent pool for queue depth.
2. If there is capacity, select next test to run (based on when it was run last)
3. Queue it.

This could probably be implemented as an Azure Function which just runs on a loop every minute or so. It could potentially run based on event notifications from Azure Pipelines so that it checks the queue depth every time it gets a notification of a build/job completing.

items.title: Check for usage of TaskCreationOptions.RunContinuationsAsynchronously
[APIView] Support a 'comment' token kind
items.body:
In the Java API tooling we've recently introduced support for showing private constructors, when there are no public constructors in the class, so that the reviewer knows that the class is not able to be instantiated using a 'new' operator (as opposed to classes that have no constructors defined, and therefore an implicit default constructor exists - which we also add in for the reviewers improved understanding).

However, now that I see it in action, e.g. [here](https://apiview.dev/Assemblies/Review/bc9e446581a4475ca4df0a011c152da7#com.azure.cosmos.CosmosScripts), I think it can be a little confusing to reviewers, who might not note that it is a non-public constructor.

What I'm leaning towards doing is instead replacing this with a comment in the APIView, e.g. instead of this:

`CosmosScripts(CosmosContainer container, CosmosAsyncScripts asyncScripts) {}`

I would have this:

`// This class does not have any public constructors, and is not able to be instantiated using 'new'`

My main ask therefore is to consider whether we could have a 'comment' token kind, and some CSS that renders it in an appropriate font and colour.

items.title: [Java] Private static inner class should not be shown
items.body:
https://apiview.dev/Assemblies/Review/6af850ed7eb04843a6897afbe13cdd28#com.azure.messaging.servicebus.ServiceBusSenderAsyncClient.AmqpMessageCollector

`AmqpMessageCollector` is a private static inner class. It should not be shown.

items.title: Update change log is adding existing version
items.body:
Update change log script is triggered automatically after release and this has caused an issue for java package if someone manually edits change log without updating the version to prepare for the release. Scenario is as follows:

- Change log for package pkg1 is updated with new version manually and didn't update the version in centralized version file.
- package pkg2 is released and this triggers auto version bump and change log update
- Version bump tool calls update change edit script for all packages and it triggers this for pkg1 also with old version in centralized version file.

Update change log script currently compares against only latest version and adds version passed as arg to change log if it doesn't match.

Fix: We should search and make sure version is not present in change log before adding instead of just comparing against latest version in log.

items.title: [Bug-Java] Nested interface is not shown.
items.body:
The nested interface is not shown here, but it should be shown because it is an interface defined in an interface. Anything in an interface is public by default.

For example, https://apiview.dev/Assemblies/Review/bc9e446581a4475ca4df0a011c152da7
The Azure search API view doesn't show the inner nested interface [BuilderDefinition](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/blob/master/sdk/cosmos/microsoft-azure-cosmos/src/main/java/com/azure/data/cosmos/ChangeFeedProcessor.java#L79) within the public interface ChangeFeedProcessor.

items.title: [doc-warden] Allow selective omission of subfolders
items.body:
Right now, the way the omission works, is that we omit "everything under" X path.

Looks like the following in config:

```
omitted_paths:
  - archive/*
```

However, what happens if we only want to omit packages under a specific path...but not the children of that path?

For example: `sdk/keyvault/README.md`

This is the service level readme for keyvault, NOT something that we should accountable to the repository standards for package readmes. 

However, we definitely _do not_ want to exclude errors on the below packages! One such readme could occur on

`sdk/keyvault/Azure.Security.Keyvault.Keys/README.md.`

Given that we use `fnmatch` internally, doc-warden won't match an omission that doesn't include the trailing `*`. This means that we cannot currently support omitting a single directory and scanning the rest below it.

Need to swap the omission list discovery to less generalized function for just the omitted files discovery.

items.title: Improve client ctor analyzer to allow for scenarios where one client option types is used across multiple clients

items.title: ApiView: Add .NET Assembly Version to "Rev N" title
items.body: To make diffing between API versions a little easier, it would be awesome to include the .NET Assembly Version in that revision title so I could do Latest against 12.0.0, 12.1.0, etc., which are a little more meaningful than Rev3, Rev6, etc.

items.title: ApiView: Show .NET's [EditorBrowsable] attribute in listings
items.body:
Now that we're getting listings for updated releases instead of fresh new libraries, we're starting to see APIs get versioned.  A lot of our patterns use `[EditorBrowsable(Never)]` to hide the old API that exists for binary compat, but the listing doesn't make that clear.  Including this attribute would help make these versioning choices clear.

See https://apiview.dev/Assemblies/Review/425aad3e8a4d4bcb9219af84e5f94f92 for an example where it would be helpful.

items.title: Python CI shows warning about overwriting a read only task variable 'OSName'
items.body:
Verify agent OS step in pipeline (~~~verify-agent-os.yml@azure-sdk-tools~~~) overwrites OSName variable and this is causing a warning as shown below.


~~~
##[warning]Overwriting readonly task variable 'OSName'. This behavior will be disabled in the future. See https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-yaml/blob/master/design/readonly-variables.md for details.
~~~

items.title: Move TestResources scripts to eng/common
items.body:
>After this goes through and the pipeline runs, should I move the TestResource scripts and replace them with stubs as we discussed?

Yes once this is goes in and starts running then you can move your test resource scripts into the eng\common directory and watch the updates flow :)

_Originally posted by @weshaggard in https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/pull/353#issuecomment-578242067_

items.title: ApiView "+1" button for comments
items.body:
It'd be nice to add a "+1" or "thumbs up" button for ApiView comments so architects could add more weight to existing comments and underscore the importance of a suggestion to a partner team.  

Partners could also use it to indicate agreement without having to resolve the comment chain that might contain multiple discussions about the same line in the API review.

items.title: Would be nice to use Ctrl+Enter to add comments
items.body: Like in GitHub, would be nice to be able to use Ctrl+Enter to add (rather, commit) comments.

items.title: Infinite redirect if user doesn't have the github org
Analyze async using statement without braces.
Add mechanism to have a script folder automatically sync to all languages repos
items.body:
There are more and more cases where we need to have some common scripts across our language repos (changelogs, file lengths, readme parsing, etc). To help with this problem we should create a common directory that we automatically sync across languages. Here is a proposal:

1) We create an `eng\common` directory in this repo. That directory will contain common text based scripts that we need to use locally or in our pipelines across the different language repos. It should remain relatively small in size and only contain scripts we need in most, if not all, our language repos. In can also contain common yml templates we need to share. 
2) We create a mechanism that automatically detects changes in the `eng/common` directory in this repo and blindly put those in all the `eng/common` directories of the repositories that are subscribed to sync these changes.

cc @azure/azure-sdk-eng

items.title: Resource Provisioner: add retries to network calls
items.body:
We've seen an error on `Connect-AzAccount` in a pipeline execution where other jobs have succeeded on this call. The cause might be a transient network issue. To that end we could wrap network calls in retries with some detection of transient errors (e.g. network timeout, 5xx status code, etc.) and retry on errors that look transient. 

Logs of this behavior: https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build/results?buildId=234118&view=logs&jobId=42c9484e-bad6-5a7b-ceb1-abf0d427bbf2&j=42c9484e-bad6-5a7b-ceb1-abf0d427bbf2&t=05996a6a-8093-5d15-a4af-44930c1872b9

items.title: update_pr pipeline is failing for private branch
items.body:
Error message: Could not get latest source version from github using commit reference. 

Additional info from trouble shooting:
This reference is pointing to correct code base when used against public repo azure-sdk-for-python. So issue seems to be in replicating(cloning) tool which is supposed to move commits in public repo to private repo.

items.title: API View - Warn users before uploading same file name in new review
items.body:
If a user attempts to upload a file as a new review for a file that already has an existing review, provide them the options of:
1) Upload to existing review (what to do if there are multiple existing reviews?)
2) Upload as new review
3) Just go to the existing review.

items.title: Docwarden has hard coded dependency on file locations in Java repo.
items.body:
A recent change to Docwarden:

https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/commit/90793333756e3cc91a44aba4414232ba44655279

Introduced a hard-coded dependency on the location of the client SDK parent POM. As part of some restructuring work we want to move the parent into ```sdk/parents/azure-client-sdk-parent/pom.xml```. We could potentially just fix up this path, but I wonder whether it is a good thing to have hard coded paths specified in code in the ```azure-sdk-tools``` repo which makes assumptions about the structure of another repo.

Additionally, post parent POM restructuring the parent POM won't contain a module listing, which means the logic being used here wouldn't work anyway.

/cc @chidozieononiwu this was a fairly recent change ... is it easy to back out, and if so what are the consequences?

items.title: Pipeline Generation for alternative pipelines
items.body: The pipeline generator needs to be updated to support generation of pipelines for alternative files, for example ```ci.data.yml``` and ```ci.mgmt.yml```. We'll basically need to have some kind of mapping from data/mgmt to convention so that if we need to mutate the convention used based on the alternative pipeline we can.

items.title: [Bug] Generating enum members without individual IDs causing comment duplication,
items.body: when a comment is added, it gets duplicated for each enum value because we don't have individual IDs for each enum member
